1. Ad Hominem - The fallacy of Ad Hominem occurs when someone attacks the person making an argument rather than the argument itself. In this example, the tweet from @avecvous calls the individual a psychopath and a charlatan, which is an attack on their character rather than engaging with their argument.

2. Appeal to Tradition - The fallacy of Appeal to Tradition occurs when someone argues that because something has been done a certain way for a long time, it is the correct or best way to do it. In this example, @dupontaignan criticizes Macron's handling of the Covid situation by highlighting changes made, such as the suppression of 17,300 beds, as evidence of a negative development.

3. Appeal to Emotions - The fallacy of Appeal to Emotions occurs when someone attempts to manipulate emotions in order to win an argument. In this example, @MLP_officiel appeals to the emotion of pride and the desire for a fair democratic process by criticizing Macron for refusing to participate in debates.

4. False Dichotomy - The fallacy of False Dichotomy occurs when someone presents a situation as having only two possible outcomes or options when there are actually more. In this example, @JLMelenchon presents the political landscape as divided into three equal blocks, simplifying the complexity of political ideologies and alliances.

5. Straw Man - The fallacy of Straw Man occurs when someone misrepresents their opponent's argument in order to make it easier to attack and refute. In this example, @UPR_Asselineau criticizes Macron for being arrogant and states they will vote for @MLP_officiel, creating a false and exaggerated characterization of Macron's behavior in the debate.
